dialogue: Look at the point on this number line. It's at the last tick mark, showing four-fourths.
prompt: Which statement explains why 4/4 is the same as one whole?

options.text: We have all the parts, so it makes a complete whole

correct_answer.context: When all parts are present (4 out of 4), they combine to make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Right. All 4 parts out of 4 makes one whole.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Think about what happens when we have all the parts.
Let's think about this more carefully. The number line shows 4 equal parts from 0 to 4/4. When we have all 4 parts out of 4, what does that mean? We're not missing any parts.

Let me walk you through this. The number line is divided into fourths - 4 equal parts. When we look at 4/4, the numerator tells us we have 4 parts, and the denominator tells us the whole is made of 4 parts. So 4/4 means we have all 4 parts out of the 4 parts that make the whole. When we have all the parts, nothing is missing, so we have one complete whole. That's why the answer is 'We have all the parts, so it makes a complete whole.' When the numerator and denominator are the same, we always have one whole because we have all the parts.
